sen.j: 虎口（こぐち）とは中世以降の城郭における出入り口のことで、「こぐち」には狭い道・狭い口という意味がある。
sen.e: Koguchi is an entrance fixed to castle walls built in the medieval period and afterward, and 'koguchi' means narrow path and narrow entrance.
Koguchi is an entrance fixed to castle walls built in the medieval period and afterward, and 'koguchi' means narrow path and narrow entrance.
Koguchi is an entrance fixed to castle walls built in the medieval period and afterward, and 'koguchi' means narrow path and narrow entrance.

sen.j: 「小口」とも書く。
sen.e: Other kanji characters have been used to represent Koguchi such as '小口.'
Other kanji characters have been used to represent Koguchi, such as '小口.'
Other kanji characters have been used to represent Koguchi, such as '小口.'

sen.j: 「虎口（ここう）」とよむ場合は、中世の戦場や陣地における危険な場所を意味する。
sen.e: When '虎口' is read Koko, it means a battlefield or a dangerous place in an encampment in the medieval period.
When '虎口' is read Koko, it means a battlefield or a dangerous place in an encampment in the medieval period.
When '虎口' is read Koko, it means a battlefield or a dangerous place in an encampment in the medieval period.

sen.j: 虎口は城郭、あるいは曲輪の正面開口に当たり、城内の軍勢にとっての出入口であった。
sen.e: Koguchi was a front opening area fixed to castle walls or Kuruwa (walls of a castle or a space reserved for various purposes,) and served as an entrance and exit for military forces of the castle.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Koguchi was a front opening area fixed to castle walls or Kuruwa (walls of a castle or a space reserved for various purposes) and served as an entrance and exit for military forces of the castle.
Koguchi was a front opening area fixed to castle walls or Kuruwa (walls of a castle or a space reserved for various purposes) and served as an entrance and exit for military forces of the castle.

sen.j: 同時に、城攻めの際には寄せ手が肉薄する攻防の要所となるため厳重に防御される。
sen.e: At the same time, if there was an attack on the castle, the enemy tried to come closer and closer to Koguchi, and the Koguchi became a key point to protect the enemy from coming in and attack them, so it was strictly secured and protected.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: At the same time, if there was an attack on the castle, the enemy tried to come closer and closer to Koguchi, and the Koguchi became a key point in defense of the castle, so it was strictly secured and protected.
sen.cmt: this gets the point across better
sen.e: At the same time, if there was an attack on the castle, the enemy tried to come closer and closer to Koguchi, and the Koguchi became a key point in defense of the castle, so it was strictly secured and protected.

sen.j: 古くは開口に木戸等の門を設け、両脇に櫓 (城郭)を建てて攻め手に備えた。
sen.e: A long time ago, a gate such as Kido was fixed in an opening section and two Yagura (tower or wooden framed stage) towers were built on the both sides near the gate for emergencies.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: A long time ago, a wooden gate was put in the open section and two turrets were built on either side near the gate for emergencies.
sen.cmt: kido won't mean anything to an English-speaking reader, nor Yagura
sen.e: A long time ago, a wooden gate was put in the open section and two turrets were built on either side near the gate for emergencies.

sen.j: 簡易なものであったが、戦国時代 (日本)に著しい発展を遂げ、城の縄張の重要要素となっていった。
sen.e: They were simple, but in the Sengoku period (period of warring states) (Japan,) the Yagura gate made a remarkable development and became a key factor for castle turf.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: They were simple, but in the Sengoku period, the Yagura gate made a remarkable development and became a key factor in castle territories.
They were simple, but in the Sengoku period (period of warring states), the Koguchi made a remarkable development and became a key factor in castle territories.
sen.cmt: 戦国時代 の説明括弧補足しました。余分なスペースを削除しました。「Yagura gate」を「Koguchi」に訂正しました。

sen.j: 西日本で桝形が発達し、東日本では馬出が発達した。
sen.e: In the western part of Japan, Masugata style was developed and in the eastern part of Japan, Umadashi style (a style of defensive gateway barrier of castles) was developed.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。「桝形」と「馬出」だけでは何か分かりづらいので、”桝形タイプ、馬出タイプ”にしました。
sen.e: The Masugata style was developed in western Japan, and the Umadashi style (a style of defensive gateway barrier of castles) in the eastern part.
The Masugata style was developed in western Japan, and the Umadashi style (a style of defensive gateway barrier of castles) in the eastern part.

sen.j: 時間の経過や統一政権の出現で技術的融合がおこり、しだいに枡形は東日本にも、馬出しは西日本にも広がっていった。
sen.e: As the time passed and the unified authority appeared, technological integration occurred, and the Masugata style and the Umadashi style were gradually spreading in the eastern part of Japan and in the western part of Japan too, respectively.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: As time passed and a unified authority appeared, technological integration occurred, and the Masugata and Umadashi styles both gradually spread throughout Japan.
As time passed and a unified authority appeared, technological integration occurred, and the Masugata and Umadashi styles both gradually spread throughout Japan.

sen.j: やがて内側に枡形、外側に馬出しと、両形態の虎口を二重に構え防備をより厳重にした城も現れた。
sen.e: In the meantime, to ensure the strict protection and security of a castle, a castle equipped with two Koguchi, Masugata style inside Umadashi style appeared.
In the meantime, to ensure strict protection and security, castles equipped with two Koguchi, Masugata style inside Umadashi style, appeared.
In the meantime, to ensure strict protection and security, castles equipped with two Koguchi, Masugata style inside Umadashi style, appeared.

sen.j: 会津若松城は、馬出し形状の北出丸、西出丸を外側に備え、その内側は桝形を備える二重構造となっていた。
sen.e: Aizu Wakamatsu-jo Castle consists of two Koguchi, Masugata style inside Umadashi style Kita (north) demaru (small castle or tower built onto and projecting from a larger castle) and Nishi (west) demaru.
Aizu Wakamatsu-jo Castle has of two Koguchi, Masugata style inside Umadashi style, for the north demaru (a small castle or tower built onto and projecting from a larger castle) and the west demaru.
sen.cmt: I venture to guess that the castle “consists of” more than just two gates, so I changed that to “has”also there is no reason for “kita” and “nishi” to remain in the English translation
sen.e: Aizu Wakamatsu-jo Castle has of two Koguchi, Masugata style inside Umadashi style, for the north demaru (a small castle or tower built onto and projecting from a larger castle) and the west demaru.

sen.j: この構造は門扉が砲撃の死角となるようにできており、幕末戊辰戦争では緒戦において北出丸の追手門を突破しようとした新政府軍の阻止に成功し、長期籠城戦に持ち込んだ。
sen.e: This structure helped the gate door to be in the dead angle from attack, and in many battles of Boshin War occurred at the end of Edo period, they were successful in preventing the New Government Army from breaking through Kita demaru Ottemon gate, resulting in the tact of holding the castle for a long time.

This structure helped the gate door to be in a blind spot in an attack, and in many battles of the Boshin War at the end of Edo period, they were successful in preventing the New Government Army from breaking through Kita demaru Ottemon gate, allowing the castle to be held for a long time.

This structure helped the gate door to be in a blind spot in an attack, and in many battles of the Boshin War at the end of Edo period, they were successful in preventing the New Government Army from breaking through Kita demaru Ottemon gate, allowing the castle to be held for a long time.

sen.j: もっとも基本的な形態は平入り（ひらいり）と呼ばれるもので堀、土塁（石垣）などで曲輪を構成してその真正面に虎口を備えるものであった。
sen.e: The most basic style of Koguchi was Hira iri (a style of building which has the entrance on the long side of building), in which Kuruwa made of moat or dorui (earthwork) (stone walls) was equipped with Koguchi in its center.
The most basic style of Koguchi was Hira iri (with the entrance on the long side of the building), in which a Koguchi was inside a moat or earthwork.
The most basic style of Koguchi was Hirairi (with the entrance on the long side of the building), in which a Koguchi was inside a moat or earthwork.

sen.j: この場合、大軍で押し寄せた寄せ手を正面から防ぐことになり城側に不利となる。
sen.e: This style was intended to protect the gate from surging large armies at the front, that was a disadvantage for the castle.
This style was intended to protect the gate from surging large armies at the front, that was a disadvantage for the castle.
This style was intended to protect the gate from surging large armies at the front, that was a disadvantage for the castle.

sen.j: そこで特に中世山城では虎口前面を急な坂とすることで寄せ手の勢いを削ぐ構造が採られた。
sen.e: Instead, in mountain castles (castles built on the top of mountains or halfway up the mountains) built in the medieval period, a very steep approach was constructed before Koguchi to cut down the enemy's power.
In mountain castles built in the medieval period, a very steep approach was instead constructed before the Koguchi to slow the enemy's advance.
sen.cmt: I think “mountain castle” is clear enough by itself
sen.e: In mountain castles built in the medieval period, a very steep approach was instead constructed before the Koguchi to slow the enemy's advance.

sen.j: これを坂虎口（さかこぐち）などという。
sen.e: This is called Saka koguchi.
This is called Saka koguchi.
This is called Saka koguchi.

sen.j: 虎口の内側に「蔀（しとみ）」や、虎口の外側に「芎（かざし）」と呼ばれる一文字形（一直線）の防塁（土塁や石垣など）を構築し、前面から郭内が容易に視認できないようにしたものも現れ、一文字虎口（いちもんじこぐち）と呼ばれた。
sen.e: To make the inside of a castle easily invisible and unrecognizable at the front, a new style of Koguchi called Ichimonji koguchi was built, in which a straight-line bulwark (earthwork, stone walls, etc.) called 'Shitomi' (a wooden lattice door which opens up vertically) was installed inside Koguchi or the one called 'Kazashi' (walls, embankments, or plants used to prevent the enemy from seeing the activities inside a castle) was installed outside Koguchi.

To hide the inside of a castle make the front unrecognizable, a new style of Koguchi called Ichimonji koguchi was built, in which a straight-line bulwark called 'Shitomi' (a wooden lattice door that opens up vertically) was installed inside Koguchi, or another style called 'Kazashi' (walls, embankments, or plants used to prevent the enemy from seeing activities inside a castle) was installed outside Koguchi.

To hide the inside of a castle make the front unrecognizable, a new style of Koguchi called Ichimonji koguchi was built, in which a straight-line bulwark called 'Shitomi' (a wooden lattice door that opens up vertically) was installed inside Koguchi, or another style called 'Kazashi' (walls, embankments, or plants used to prevent the enemy from seeing activities inside a castle) was installed outside Koguchi.

sen.j: 合戦が大規模になってくるとさらに虎口の重要性は増し、城郭の防衛力向上のため、堀、土塁、石垣の配置に工夫が施されるようになる。
sen.e: As battle scale became larger, the importance of Koguchi increased, and people started to carefully design the location of moat, earthwork or stone walls to enhance the defense capability of castle walls.

As the scale of battles became larger, the importance of Koguchi increased, and much care was given to the design and location of moats, earthworks and stone walls to enhance the defensive capability of castle walls.

As the scale of battles became larger, the importance of Koguchi increased, and much care was given to the design and location of moats, earthworks and stone walls to enhance the defensive capability of castle walls.

sen.j: 喰違虎口（くいちがいこぐち）は土塁や石垣を平行ではなく、食い違いにすることによって、開口部を側面に設け、攻城側はS字の進路を取らざるを得なくなった。
sen.e: In Kuichigai-koguchi entrance, earthwork or stone walls were placed or built in a different direction, respectively, not in parallel, and as a result, an entrance was constructed at the side so that the enemy was compelled to follow the S shape pathway.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In Kuichigai-koguchi entrances, earthworks or stone walls were built in different directions, not in parallel, and an entrance was constructed at the side so that the enemy was compelled to follow the S-shaped pathway.

In Kuichigai-koguchi entrances, earthworks or stone walls were built in different directions, not in parallel, and an entrance was constructed at the side so that the enemy was compelled to follow the S-shaped pathway.

sen.j: さらに側面からの射出攻撃も受けやすくなるという構造となっている。
sen.e: Also, the structure allowed an enemy to be vulnerable to attack from the side using a gun or arrow.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Also, the structure made enemies vulnerable to attack from the side by guns or arrows.
Also, the structure made enemies vulnerable to attack from the side by guns or arrows.

sen.j: 戦国末期には西日本を中心に枡形（ますがた）と呼ばれる虎口が現れた。
sen.e: At the end of the Sengoku period, Koguchi called Masugata appeared mainly in the west part of Japan.
At the end of the Sengoku period, Koguchi called Masugata appeared mainly in the west part of Japan.
At the end of the Sengoku period, Koguchi called Masugata appeared mainly in the west part of Japan.

sen.j: これは虎口の前面に方形の空間を設け、そこに門や口を2重に構えた。
sen.e: This was a square enclosure-style one with a gate or entrance and was placed in front of Koguchi to double protection.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This was a square enclosure with a gate or entrance and was placed in front of a Koguchi to double protection.
This was a square enclosure with a gate or entrance and was placed in front of a Koguchi to double protection.

sen.j: 攻撃側は桝形内部に侵入しても2番目の門に城内への侵入を阻まれ、桝形内部で守備側からの攻撃を全面に浴びることとなる。
sen.e: As a result of the construction of the two gates or entrances, even if an enemy could managed to enter the Masugata enclosure through the first gate, they were prevented from going in the castle ground by the second gate, and were apt to be attacked in the Masugata area.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: As a result of the construction of the two gates, even if an enemy could managed to enter the Masugata enclosure through the first gate, they were prevented from entering the castle ground by the second gate, and were vulnerable to attack in the Masugata area.

As a result of the construction of the two gates, even if an enemy could managed to enter the Masugata enclosure through the first gate, they were prevented from entering the castle ground by the second gate, and were vulnerable to attack in the Masugata area.

sen.j: 枡形には内枡形（うちますがた）と外枡形（そとますがた）がある。
sen.e: There were two styles of Masugata: Uchi-masugata (a type of walled compound, in the shape of a square measuring box masu, inside the entrance to a defensive installation) and Soto-masugata (a type of masugata, built outside the castle entrance.)

There were two styles of Masugata: Uchi-masugata (a type of walled compound, in the shape of a square measuring box, or masu, inside the entrance to a defensive installation) and Soto-masugata (a type of masugata, built outside the castle entrance).

There were two styles of Masugata: Uchi-masugata (a type of walled compound, in the shape of a square measuring box, or masu, inside the entrance to a defensive installation) and Soto-masugata (a type of masugata, built outside the castle entrance).

sen.j: 内枡形は、曲輪の虎口の内側に小さな方形空間を造り第二の門を築く。
sen.e: Uchi-masugata was an inner enclosure placed inside Koguchi in Kuruwa, and a gate was fixed to it to make the second gate.
Uchi-masugata was an inner enclosure placed inside Koguchi in Kuruwa, and a gate was fixed to it to make the second gate.
Uchi-masugata was an inner enclosure placed inside Koguchi in Kuruwa, and a gate was fixed to it to make the second gate.

sen.j: ここに入り込むと寄せ手は3方向から囲まれる。
sen.e: Upon entry of an enemy into the Uchi-masugata, they would be surrounded from three directions.
Upon entry into the Uchi-masugata, the enemy would be surrounded from three directions.
Upon entry into the Uchi-masugata, the enemy would be surrounded from three directions.

sen.j: 外枡形は、主な曲輪の虎口の外に地続きの小さな方形空間を張り出させ、最前にもう1つの門を開いたものである。
sen.e: Soto-masugata was an enclosure projected outside the main Koguchi in Kuruwa, and a gate was fixed to it to make another gate at the forefront.
Soto-masugata was an enclosure projected outside the main Koguchi in Kuruwa, and a gate was fixed to it to make another gate at the forefront.
Soto-masugata was an enclosure projected outside the main Koguchi in Kuruwa, and a gate was fixed to it to make another gate at the forefront.

sen.j: 枡形の門は、最前の門とその後方の門の2つが開かれる。
sen.e: In Masugatamon gate, a front gate and a rear gate were opened.
In Masugatamon gate, a front gate and a rear gate were opened.
In Masugatamon gate, a front gate and a rear gate were opened.

sen.j: 最前の門を高麗門、その後方の門を櫓門としたものが基本的な形状であると見られているが、後方の門のみで最前の門がないものや、最前の門のみのものもある。
sen.e: The basic type seems to have been composed of Korai-mon Gate as a front gate and Yagura-mon Gate as a rear gate, but some Masugatamon gates had only a rear gate without a front gate and others had only a front gate.

The basic type seems to have been composed of Korai-mon Gate as a front gate and Yagura-mon Gate as a rear gate, but some Masugatamon gates had only a rear gate without a front gate and others had only a front gate.

The basic type seems to have been composed of Korai-mon Gate as a front gate and Yagura-mon Gate as a rear gate, but some Masugatamon gates had only a rear gate without a front gate and others had only a front gate.

sen.j: 近世城郭はその多くが枡形、あるいはそれに類する虎口を備え、侵入した攻撃側が容易に直進できないようにするため右折または左折構造を採る場合が多い。
sen.e: Castle walls constructed in the Azuchi and Edo period were mostly equipped Masugata type or the similar types of Koguchi, and to prevent an enemy from easily proceeding straight, many of the paths following the first gate were designed to bend to the right or left.

Castle walls constructed in the Azuchi and Edo periods mostly had Masugata or similar types of Koguchi, and to prevent an enemy from easily proceeding straight, many of the paths following the first gate were designed to bend to the right or left.

Castle walls constructed in the Azuchi and Edo periods mostly had Masugata or similar types of Koguchi, and to prevent an enemy from easily proceeding straight, many of the paths following the first gate were designed to bend to the right or left.

sen.j: 枡形とは別に東日本中心に発展した虎口の形態が馬出（うまだし）である。
sen.e: Separate from Masugata, a Koguchi type developed in the eastern part of Japan was Umadashi.
Separate from Masugata, a Koguchi type developed in the eastern part of Japan was Umadashi.
Separate from Masugata, a Koguchi type developed in the eastern part of Japan was Umadashi.

sen.j: 堀に面する虎口の外側に、弧状またはコの字型に土塁や石垣を積みできる小規模な曲輪である。
sen.e: Umadashi was a small Kuruwa placed outside of Koguchi facing a moat, and was made in arc shape or U-shape by heaping up dorui (earthwork) or constructing stone walls.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Umadashi was a small Kuruwa placed outside of Koguchi facing a moat, and was made in arc shape or U-shape by heaping up earth or constructing stone walls.
Umadashi was a small Kuruwa placed outside of Koguchi facing a moat, and was made in arc shape or U-shape by heaping up earth or constructing stone walls.

sen.j: 出入りできる部分を残して周りに堀を穿つ。
sen.e: Moats were constructed around the Umadashi, leaving a small part of land available for a path.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Moats were constructed around the Umadashi, leaving a small part of land available for a path.
Moats were constructed around the Umadashi, leaving a small part of land available for a path.

sen.j: これが大型化したものを馬出曲輪という。
sen.e: A large type of Umadashi was called Umadashi kuruwa.
A large type of Umadashi was called Umadashi kuruwa.
A large type of Umadashi was called Umadashi kuruwa.

sen.j: 大坂城に築かれたの真田丸のように、出郭（でぐるわ）、出丸（でまる）には馬出曲輪の形状をしたのがある。
sen.e: Some of Deguruwa (a compound that juts out or is slightly separated from the main components of castle complex) and Demaru (small castle or tower built onto and projecting from a larger castle) were the Umadashi kuruwa style and the Sanada-maru (Sanada Barbican) constructed in Osaka Castle's ground is a good example.

Some Deguruwa (compounds that jut out or are slightly separated from the main components of a castle complex) and Demaru (small towers built onto and projecting from a larger castle) were made in the Umadashi kuruwa style, and the Sanada-maru at Osaka Castle is a good example.

Some Deguruwa (compounds that jut out or are slightly separated from the main components of a castle complex) and Demaru (small towers built onto and projecting from a larger castle) were made in the Umadashi kuruwa style, and the Sanada-maru at Osaka Castle is a good example.
